text.p: Sterling ended a bumpy European session down on the day, unable to profit from a generally weak mark as subdued UK PPI data cast a question mark over expectations of a near-term interest rate rise, traders said.

December core output prices rose just 0.1 percent on the month and 0.8 on the year, while headline output increases were 0.5 and 1.7 percent respectively. Input prices fell 0.5 percent on the month and 5.9 percent on the year, less than forecast.
"The PPI figures were fairly calm, so people looking for interest rate hikes this week...may be somewhat disappointed," said Peter Wood, forex dealer at Bank of Boston in London.

The data will strengthen Chancellor Kenneth Clarke's hand if he argues against raising interest rates at his monthly monetary meeting with Bank of England governor Eddie George on Wednesday, analysts said.

"If the Chancellor wants to keep interest rates steady at Wednesday's monetary meeting, this morning's PPIs give him useful ammunition with which to argue his case," said Jeremy Hawkins, economic adviser at Bank of America here.
Sterling was trading at 2.6515/25 marks by 1537 GMT, off a session low of 2.6460 but below the day's peak of 2.6670 and down from late Friday's European level of 2.6660/70.
Against the dollar, it softened to $1.6678/88 from $1.6818/28 late on Friday, and was down on a trade-weighted basis to 95.7 from the previous close of 96.1.
